0.00.text:
Translator: Timothy Covell
Reviewer: Morton Bast

15.62.text: In half a century of trying to help prevent wars,

19.75.text: there's one question that never leaves me:

23.29.text: How do we deal with extreme violence

33.04.text: whether it's a child facing a bully on a playground

37.65.text: or, on the streets of Syria today,

43.12.text: what's the most effective thing to do?

52.44.text: This question: "How do I deal with a bully

56.40.text: without becoming a thug in return?"

60.15.text: has been with me ever since I was a child.

65.72.text: glued to a grainy black and white television in my parents' living room

70.70.text: as Soviet tanks rolled into Budapest,

74.97.text: and kids not much older than me

77.77.text: were throwing themselves at the tanks

82.43.text: And I rushed upstairs and started packing my suitcase.

86.24.text: And my mother came up and said, "What on Earth are you doing?"

88.95.text: And I said, "I'm going to Budapest."

91.23.text: And she said, "What on Earth for?"

93.87.text: And I said, "Kids are getting killed there.

97.77.text: And she said, "Don't be so silly."

102.38.text: And she got it, she said,

106.37.text: You're much too young to help.

109.20.text: You need training. I'll help you.

114.00.text: And so I got some training

117.57.text: and went and worked in Africa during most of my 20s.

121.50.text: But I realized that what I really needed to know

125.20.text: I couldn't get from training courses.

134.23.text: And what I've discovered since is this:

139.18.text: Bullies use violence in three ways.

143.25.text: They use political violence to intimidate,

153.97.text: and mental or emotional violence to undermine.

161.49.text: And only very rarely in very few cases

164.72.text: does it work to use more violence.

168.23.text: Nelson Mandela went to jail believing in violence,

180.43.text: honed the skills, the incredible skills, that they needed

185.40.text: to turn one of the most vicious governments the world has known

191.47.text: And they did it in a total devotion to non-violence.

196.20.text: They realized that using force against force

210.75.text: Over time I've collected about a half-dozen methods

214.22.text: that do work -- of course there are many more --

216.06.text: that do work and that are effective.

219.77.text: that the change that has to take place

222.29.text: has to take place here, inside me.

226.75.text: It's my response, my attitude, to oppression

233.70.text: and that I can do something about.

236.00.text: And what I need to develop is self-knowledge to do that.

240.19.text: That means I need to know how I tick,

253.24.text: What will I stand up for?

263.64.text: is one of the ways -- again it's not the only one --

267.29.text: of gaining this kind of inner power.

271.41.text: And my heroine here -- like Satish's --

273.89.text: is Aung San Suu Kyi in Burma.

276.92.text: She was leading a group of students

280.55.text: on a protest in the streets of Rangoon.

282.95.text: They came around a corner faced with a row of machine guns.

288.30.text: that the soldiers with their fingers shaking on the triggers

292.22.text: were more scared than the student protesters behind her.

297.92.text: But she told the students to sit down.

300.63.text: And she walked forward with such calm and such clarity

307.92.text: and such total lack of fear

311.37.text: that she could walk right up to the first gun,

315.47.text: put her hand on it and lower it.

327.36.text: So that's what the mastery of fear can do --

331.30.text: not only faced with machine guns,

333.60.text: but if you meet a knife fight in the street.

350.43.text: on the energy I feed it.

352.64.text: And if it grows very big

357.29.text: So we all know the three o'clock in the morning syndrome,

361.73.text: when something you've been worrying about wakes you up --

364.44.text: I see a lot of people --

366.83.text: and for an hour you toss and turn,

372.12.text: and by four o'clock you're pinned to the pillow

379.38.text: is to get up, make a cup of tea

381.22.text: and sit down with the fear like a child beside you.

390.90.text: And you talk to the fear

392.34.text: and you ask it what it wants, what it needs.

395.53.text: How can this be made better?

400.15.text: How can the child feel stronger?

403.35.text: And you say, "Okay, now we're going back to sleep.

405.35.text: Half-past seven, we're getting up and that's what we're going to do."

409.12.text: I had one of these 3 a.m. episodes on Sunday --

414.87.text: paralyzed with fear at coming to talk to you.

422.36.text: I got up, made the cup of tea, sat down with it, did it all

426.49.text: and I'm here -- still partly paralyzed, but I'm here.

435.04.text: So that's fear. What about anger?

437.56.text: Wherever there is injustice there's anger.

444.81.text: and if you spray it around and somebody lights a match,

450.26.text: But anger as an engine -- in an engine -- is powerful.

455.38.text: If we can put our anger inside an engine,

461.33.text: it can get us through the dreadful moments

464.31.text: and it can give us real inner power.

468.28.text: And I learned this in my work

473.66.text: Because at the beginning I was so outraged

476.38.text: at the dangers they were exposing us to

479.69.text: that I just wanted to argue and blame and make them wrong.

487.36.text: In order to develop a dialogue for change

491.11.text: we have to deal with our anger.

493.18.text: It's okay to be angry with the thing --

497.86.text: the nuclear weapons in this case --

499.96.text: but it is hopeless to be angry with the people.

503.81.text: They are human beings just like us.

506.43.text: And they're doing what they think is best.

509.08.text: And that's the basis on which we have to talk with them.

513.06.text: So that's the third one, anger.

515.98.text: And it brings me to the crux

517.38.text: of what's going on, or what I perceive as going on,

521.68.text: which is that last century was top-down power.

525.69.text: It was still governments telling people what to do.

535.88.text: It's like mushrooms coming through concrete.

539.09.text: It's people joining up with people, as Bundy just said, miles away

548.05.text: And Peace Direct spotted quite early on

552.31.text: that local people in areas of very hot conflict

558.30.text: They know best what to do.

560.52.text: So Peace Direct gets behind them to do that.

563.80.text: And the kind of thing they're doing

579.62.text: And they have to risk their lives almost every day

589.52.text: is that using violence in the situations they operate in

601.11.text: than using methods that connect people with people, that rebuild.

607.64.text: And I think that the U.S. military

611.57.text: is finally beginning to get this.

618.45.text: Up to now their counter-terrorism policy

621.16.text: has been to kill insurgents at almost any cost,

625.99.text: and if civilians get in the way,

633.46.text: And this is so infuriating and humiliating

642.54.text: that it makes the recruitment for al-Qaeda very easy,

646.89.text: when people are so disgusted by, for example,

652.44.text: So the training of the troops has to change.

655.44.text: And I think there are signs that it is beginning to change.

660.55.text: The British military have always been much better at this.

663.33.text: But there is one magnificent example for them to take their cue from,

669.01.text: and that's a brilliant U.S. lieutenant colonel

673.85.text: And he was leading his men down the streets of Najaf --

680.23.text: and suddenly people were pouring out of the houses on either side of the road,

689.86.text: and surrounded these very young troops who were completely terrified,

694.33.text: didn't know what was going on, couldn't speak Arabic.

696.83.text: And Chris Hughes strode into the middle of the throng

701.08.text: with his weapon above his head, pointing at the ground,

709.45.text: with their backpacks and their body armor,

725.20.text: everybody moved aside and went home.

729.47.text: Now that to me is wisdom in action.

734.96.text: In the moment, that's what he did.

750.45.text: why and how so many dictatorships have collapsed

774.19.text: Serbia, Slovenia, I could go on,

787.92.text: A lot of it is due to a book

791.07.text: written by an 80-year-old man in Boston, Gene Sharp.

795.53.text: He wrote a book called "From Dictatorship to Democracy"

804.95.text: And it's been translated into 26 languages.

809.12.text: And it's being used by young people and older people everywhere,

816.30.text: because it works and it's effective.

821.73.text: So this is what gives me hope --

826.28.text: not just hope, this is what makes me feel very positive right now.

830.04.text: Because finally human beings are getting it.

843.25.text: How do we deal with a bully without becoming a thug?

849.56.text: We're using the kind of skills that I've outlined:

853.97.text: inner power -- the development of inner power -- through self-knowledge,

857.68.text: recognizing and working with our fear,

871.45.text: and most importantly, commitment to active non-violence.

878.42.text: Now I don't just believe in non-violence.

882.53.text: I don't have to believe in it.

885.47.text: I see evidence everywhere of how it works.

889.02.text: And I see that we, ordinary people,

895.07.text: can do what Aung San Suu Kyi and Ghandi and Mandela did.

901.39.text: We can bring to an end

904.11.text: the bloodiest century that humanity has ever known.

909.11.text: And we can organize to overcome oppression

919.67.text: as well as strengthening this incredible resolve.

925.52.text: And this open-heartedness is exactly what I've experienced

930.12.text: in the entire organization of this gathering since I got here yesterday.
